Leonardo da Vinci: I would bring Leonardo da Vinci back to life. He was a true Renaissance man - an artist, inventor, engineer, and scientist. I would want to learn from him about his creative process and how he managed to excel in so many different fields. I would also ask him about his thoughts on innovation and how he saw the world as a place of endless possibility. He was a true visionary, and I believe his insights would be invaluable in today's world.

Frida Kahlo: I would bring Frida Kahlo back to life. Her art is a testament to her strength and resilience in the face of adversity. I would want to learn more about her experiences as a woman in a patriarchal society and how she used her art to express herself and her emotions. I would also ask her about her thoughts on identity and how she navigated her Mexican heritage and her experiences as a woman.

Albert Einstein: I would bring Albert Einstein back to life. He was a brilliant physicist who changed our understanding of the universe. I would want to learn from him about his theories and how he arrived at them. I would also ask him about his thoughts on the interconnectedness of all things and how he saw the universe as a complex web of relationships.

Cleopatra: I would bring Cleopatra back to life. She was a powerful and intelligent leader who navigated the complex world of ancient politics with skill and cunning. I would want to learn from her about her experiences as a woman in a male-dominated society and how she managed to maintain her power and influence. I would also ask her about her thoughts on diplomacy and how she saw the world as a place of endless possibility.

Ada Lovelace: I would bring Ada Lovelace back to life. She was a pioneering computer scientist and mathematician who saw the potential of Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine to go beyond mere calculation and perform any task that could be expressed in a series of steps. I would want to learn from her about her insights into the nature of computation and how she saw the potential for machines to think and learn. I would also ask her about her thoughts on the intersection of art and science and how she saw the world as a place of endless possibility.
